stem: Complete the staging for a pressure injury.
template: A pressure injury that presents as a shallow open ulcer with a red-pink wound bed and no slough is classified as {{stage}}. If the injury involves full-thickness tissue loss with visible subcutaneous fat, it is classified as {{stage2}}.

rationale.correct: (1) Stage 2 pressure injuries involve partial-thickness skin loss with a shallow open ulcer exhibiting a red-pink wound bed, without sloughing. This indicates damage to the epidermis and possibly the dermis, but not deeper tissues. (2) Stage 3 pressure injuries involve full-thickness tissue loss where subcutaneous fat is visible. However, muscle, tendon, or bone are not exposed. The injury extends through the dermis and into the subcutaneous tissue.
rationale.incorrect: Stage 1 pressure injuries present as intact skin with non-blanchable erythema, indicating damage to the underlying tissues but without a break in the skin. Stage 4 pressure injuries involve full-thickness tissue loss with exposed bone, tendon, or muscle. Slough or eschar may be present. Unstageable pressure injuries are those where the base of the ulcer is covered by slough and/or eschar, preventing accurate staging.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 1
answerBreakdown.content: Selecting "Stage 2" correctly identifies the pressure injury based on the description of a shallow open ulcer with a red-pink wound bed and no slough. Stage 1 would present as intact skin with non-blanchable redness. Stage 3 involves full-thickness tissue loss with visible subcutaneous fat. Unstageable involves slough or eschar covering the base of the ulcer.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 2
answerBreakdown.content: Selecting "Stage 3" correctly identifies the pressure injury based on the description of full-thickness tissue loss with visible subcutaneous fat. Stage 2 involves partial-thickness skin loss. Stage 4 involves full-thickness tissue loss with exposed bone, tendon, or muscle. Unstageable involves slough or eschar covering the base of the ulcer.

clinicalPearls: Document wound characteristics meticulously, including size, depth, exudate, and surrounding skin condition. Use the PUSH tool (Pressure Ulcer Scale for Healing) to monitor wound healing progress. Consult with a wound care specialist for complex or non-healing wounds.

SBAR Example (143 words, military time):
Situation: "This is [Your Name], RN, calling from [Unit] regarding Mr./Ms. [Patient Name], MRN [Medical Record Number], who has a suspected pressure injury."
Background: "The patient is a [Age]-year-old [Gender] admitted on [Date] for [Reason for Admission]. They have a history of [Relevant Medical History, e.g., diabetes, immobility]. A new area of skin breakdown was noted during the 0800 skin assessment."
Assessment: "The area is located on the [Location, e.g., sacrum]. It presents as a shallow open ulcer with a red-pink wound bed and no slough. Based on these findings, I believe it is a Stage 2 pressure injury. There is no sign of infection at this time. The patient denies pain at the site."
Recommendation: "I recommend we initiate pressure injury prevention protocols, including frequent repositioning (every 2 hours), pressure-redistributing support surfaces, and nutritional consult. I also recommend a wound care consult for further evaluation and management. Do you have any questions?"

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember the mnemonic 'Fat at 3, Foundation at 4'. Stage 3 involves fat, while Stage 4 involves deeper structures like muscle and bone. Also, consider the depth of tissue involvement.

mnemonic.title: Pressure Ulcer Stages: Visual Cues
mnemonic.expansion:
1: Intact, Red (Skin intact, non-blanchable redness)
2: Partial (Partial thickness skin loss)
3: Fat Visible (Full thickness, fat visible)
4: Deep (Muscle/Bone visible)

reviewUnits.heading: Pressure Injury Prevention and Management
reviewUnits.body: Implement a comprehensive pressure injury prevention plan for at-risk patients. This includes: (1) Regular skin assessments using the Braden Scale to identify risk factors. (2) Repositioning patients at least every two hours. (3) Utilizing pressure-redistributing support surfaces. (4) Ensuring adequate nutrition and hydration. (5) Maintaining skin hygiene and moisture balance. (6) Educating patients and families on pressure injury prevention strategies.
reviewUnits.source: National Pressure Injury Advisory Panel (NPIAP) Guidelines

reviewUnits.heading: Pressure Injury Staging
reviewUnits.body: Accurate staging of pressure injuries is crucial for appropriate treatment and documentation. Remember to differentiate between the stages based on the depth of tissue involvement and the presence of structures like fat, muscle, or bone. If the base of the ulcer is obscured by slough or eschar, it is considered unstageable until debridement reveals the underlying tissue.
reviewUnits.source: Wound, Ostomy and Continence Nurses Society (WOCN) Guidelines
